English (United States)(en-US): And now...
Ah, success. Gather around.
Whoaaaa.
WHOOOOOAAAAAAA!
Ahem. Hello, human. Red here.
Everyone on the Moon loves humans!
And so! Do! I!
(A crash.)
Ouch!
Calm down. Human startled.\nAnd too loud. Ears ringing.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 진정. 인간 놀람. 그리고\n시끄러워. 귀 먹먹하다.

English (United States)(en-US): Yes. Numerous errors\nmaking signal unsteady.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 응, 아직 오류가 많아서 언제\n신호가 끊어질지 모름.

English (United States)(en-US): Say hello, Cello.\nI will translate.
Wait. (Zz) Breaking.... (Zzzz)
(Sad music can be heard.)
First prototype, prone\nto malfunction.
Settings for turning on\nand off not yet an option.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 켜지고 꺼지는 타이밍도 설정이\n안 되고. 어쩔 수 없음.

English (United States)(en-US): No need to be sad. Be\nthe first to say hello next.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 지금 슬픔은 견디고, 다음에\n켜지면 제일 먼저 인사해.

English (United States)(en-US): Wonder how you’ll pull it off.
Yaaaawn. Ugh, look at the\ntime. I don’t wanna work.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 하아아아아아음. 으, 시간이\n언제 이렇게. 일하기 싫어.

English (United States)(en-US): What do you guys think of\nwhen you work?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 너희는 일할 때 무슨\n생각 하면서 청소해?

English (United States)(en-US): I don’t think. I do.
Sing?
That’s right. When Sir Cello\nhums, I make up the lyrics.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 맞아, 첼로 경이 노래하면 내가\n자막을 만들어서 같이 불러.

English (United States)(en-US): Like this!
The filthy lake is swelling high!\nScoop it up and scrape it dry!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 해괴한 호수는 차오른다!\n퍼 담고 굳히고 긁어 내자!

English (United States)(en-US): Uneven arms, twisted back!\nNo room here to cut some slack!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 짝짝이 팔다리 비틀어진 등허리!\n달 뒤편의 아래의 구석을 지키는!

English (United States)(en-US): We are the cleeeaners\nof the Moon!
Ah. Wait. Seems to be on.\nLight is on.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아. 잠시만. 켜진 것\n같음. 불 들어오네.

English (United States)(en-US): Say hello, Sir Cello.
Sir Cello! Say hi!!
(Zz) Not again (Zzzz)
Hmm. (Hums excitely)
Hmm-hmm.
Hmm-mm-hmm-mm.
Human! Ah, ahem.\nRed here.
(Pattering footsteps.)
I stole the transmitter while\nEdison had her back turned.
I wanted to show you around.\nQuick! We don’t have time!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 달나라를 보여 주고 싶어서.\n빨리! 시간이 없어!

English (United States)(en-US): First there’s (footsteps quicken)\nthe dream factory.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 우선 저어기 (발걸음이 탁탁탁\n빨라진다) 보이는 건 꿈 공장이야!

English (United States)(en-US): Beautiful, right? It’s usually\ninvisible to the human eye.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 정말 아름답지? 대부분 인간의\n눈에는 보이지 않지만.

English (United States)(en-US): But if you can see Dot,\nI bet you can see it too.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 하지만 뭉치를 볼 수 있다면\n이 공장도 볼 수 있을걸?

English (United States)(en-US): Those sparky friends over\nthere are the moon moths.
Hehe. And the ground under\nmy feet... and tada. The crater.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 흐흐. 내 발밑엔 땅바닥...\n그리고 짠. 크레이터.

English (United States)(en-US): Looks like a black lake, right?\nNo one likes it. But me?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 검은 호수 같지? 다들 끔찍하다고\n싫어하지만, 난 뭐랄까,

English (United States)(en-US): Well, looking at it somehow...\nsoothes me.
What are you doing?
What does it look like? I’m\nshowing the human around.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 뭐 하긴? 인간한테 달나라\n구경 시켜 주고 있다.

English (United States)(en-US): What. What!
What! Why are you\ngiving me that look!
Showing what.
The Factory... the moths...\nthe ground... the craters...
And I thought they’d like to see\nthe dark side of the moon...
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 지구에선 달 뒤편이 안 보이니까,\n궁금하지 않을까 하고....

English (United States)(en-US): Visual information\ncannot be transmitted.
What? You’re kidding!
Hand it over.
(Sigh) Noooo. I wanna talk more.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): (작은 한숨 소리) 아아. 싫어어.\n인간이랑 더 이야기할래.

English (United States)(en-US): And if you dropped it?\nIf it fell into a crater?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 떨어뜨리기라도 했으면 어쩔 뻔\n했음? 크레이터에 빠트렸으면?

English (United States)(en-US): Hand it over.
I need to check for damages.
(Small sigh)
Hey Edison, Sir Cello!
You know old man Chicory\nthat cleans the east part of things?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아니, 글쎄, 동쪽 구역 청소를\n맡은 치커리 영감이 말이야.

English (United States)(en-US): Says he saw a GHOST\nyesterday.
Ghosts are illusions.
Or temporary changes in\ntemporal lobe brain waves.
Are not.
False.
♮♭~♫♩...? (Trembling notes)
Do not indulge him, Sir Cello.
Hallucinations, not uncommon\nfor man of Chicory’s age.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 치커리 영감 정도라면\n환시를 볼 나이도 됐음.

English (United States)(en-US): May have mistaken a swarm\nof Moon moths for a ghost.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 자러 가던 달나방 떼를\n귀신으로 착각했을 수 있음.

English (United States)(en-US): Yeah? Boy, that’s a relief.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그런 거겠지? 안심이\n되는 것 같기도 하고.

English (United States)(en-US): I’m sure glad the four of us\nare together though.
‘Cause real or not,\nghosts are SCARY.
Wait.
Four?
Wait...? There’s no way......!
AAAAHHHHHHHHHH!
The filthy lake is swelling high!\nScoop it up and scrape it dry!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 해괴한 호수는 차오른다!\n퍼 담고 굳히고 긁어 내자!

English (United States)(en-US): Uneven arms, twisted back!\nNo room here to cut some slack!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 짝짝이 팔다리 비틀어진 등허리!\n달 뒤편의 아래의 구석을 지키는!

English (United States)(en-US): We are the cleeeaners of the Moon!
God, my back is killing me.
Perhaps.
But not due to cleaning.
You slouch during break times\nrather than sitting straight.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 네가 쉬는 동안 허리 펴기 귀찮\n다고 구부정하게 앉아서 그럼.

English (United States)(en-US): But it’s been work, work,\nwork all day with an\nextra scoop of work!
I slouch because I’m just too\npooped to do anything else.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 쉴 때엔 너무 피곤해서 웅크리고\n있어야만 살 것 같단 말이야.

English (United States)(en-US): I can’t take it anymore.\nEdison! Sir Cello!
We gotta take a leaf from\nhumans and that book of theirs.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이대로는 안 되겠어. 멋진\n어른 인간들을 본받자.

English (United States)(en-US): We’ll need a ‘home’,\nand ‘work hours’!
Hmm?
We’ll call this bonfire pit\nour ‘home.’
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이 모닥불 구덩이를 우리의\n‘집’이라고 정하는 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): Then?
Then we assign ourselves\nworkloads for each day.
Once we fill ten pits with\nMoon filth from the craters,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 크레이터에서 퍼다 나른 폐기물\n로 구덩이를 열 개 채우면

English (United States)(en-US): we’re off the clock\nand get to go ‘home’!
We’ll go back to work\nwhen the constellations\nmove... THIS much.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 별자리가 반의 반 뼘만큼 공전\n했을 때 다시 출근하는 거지!

English (United States)(en-US): Sounds interesting.\nSuggest you give it a try.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 괜찮은 것 같음. 한번 해 봐.

English (United States)(en-US): No, WE will.
All three of us!
Affirmative.
We have a home now.\nA warm bonfire... a toasty stone chair.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 집이 생겼어. 따끈한 모닥불...\n잘 구워진 돌 의자.

English (United States)(en-US): It is nice.
You think something’s missing?
Guess it’s pretty empty.
It is the dark side of the Moon.\nIt will always be empty.
But that doesn’t mean\nour souls have to be empty.
Why don’t we give\nhome decor a shot?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 우리, 집을 꾸며 보는 건 어때?

English (United States)(en-US): Hmm.
... Good. Will fetch more pebbles.
eng
eng
eng
Red, a question.
Back then.
Why suggest sending Dot to Earth?
Right before we launched Dot into space,\ndo you remember what they said?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 우리가 뭉치를 우주로 던지기\n직전, 뭉치가 했던 말 기억해?

English (United States)(en-US): Over there... Dreams...\nSomething like that.
‘Over there, someone may\nwant me as their dream.’
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): ‘저기엔 나를 꿈으로 삼아 줄\n다른 존재가 있을지도 몰라요.’

English (United States)(en-US): Yeah, right! That.
Dot,
Dot... can dream.
Dream?
A monster born of filth...\nThey are not usually welcome.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 폐기물에서 태어난 괴물....\n맞아, 유쾌한 존재는 아니지.

English (United States)(en-US): But when I looked into their eyes,\nI felt hope... or something like it.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그 검은 눈을 보고 있으면 희망...\n같은 무언가가 느껴졌어.

English (United States)(en-US): They were dark but certain.
So I thought if a human met Dot,\nthey would become happy for sure!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그걸 인간에게 보내면, 그 인간은\n분명 행복해질 것 같았어!

English (United States)(en-US): And Dot’s cute, in an ugly way.
(A string of high staccatos,\nakin to laughter.)
Difficult to wrap my lightbulb head\naround this notion. Dot, ‘cute.’
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나의 전구 머리로는 해독할 수\n없는 난해한 감상. 뭉치가 ‘귀엽다’니.

English (United States)(en-US): Okay. Why did you accept my\nsuggestion so readily then, Edison?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 에디슨, 그런 너는 내 제안을\n왜 흔쾌히 수락한 거야?

English (United States)(en-US): Your reckless, stupid, dangerous\nsuggestion, you mean?
(Bickering noises.\nRed grumbling.)
Because I believed in you.
Your plan was reckless, stupid, and\ndangerous. But still warmhearted.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 너의 계획은 무모하고 멍청하고\n위험하기까지 했지만, 따뜻했다.

English (United States)(en-US): Wanted to pin my hopes on the\nwarmth your flame-head illuminated.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 네 불꽃 대가리가 밝혀 낸 가능성에\n희망을 걸어 보고 싶었어.

English (United States)(en-US): ...... Also, my desire to see a human\novercame my rational side.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): ...... 인간을 보고 싶다는 열망이\n이성을 이겨 버린 후이기도 했고.

English (United States)(en-US): Edison! Wait up!
Huff... huff... moon butterflies\ncame at me all of a sudden.
Moon-butterflies.\nWinged insects inhabiting\nedge of craters.
Reacting to what?
Well, you know that sign that\nmarks all the cleaning spots.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그, 청소 구역 표시해 둔\n표지판 말이지.

English (United States)(en-US): I messed up and it\nkinda caught on fire.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내가 불 조절을 실수해서\n조금 태워 버렸다!

English (United States)(en-US): .....Kinda? Certain?
Just a smidge! The paper\nwas burning away when...
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 크흠, 조금! 그래서 종이가\n타닥타닥 타들어 가는데...

English (United States)(en-US): A swarm of Moon butterflies\ncame at me from the south!
Before I knew it I was\nsurrounded by them.
Wave after wave of silver\nrippling before my eyes.
Confusing, but beautiful!
Moon butterflies and their\nshimmering stardust flight.
....Edison? Where you going?
My lab.
Will investigate why Moon\nbutterflies burn in fire.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 달나비가 불에 타는 것에\n반응하는 이유를 탐구해야겠다.

English (United States)(en-US): ...Why doesn’t Sir Cello\nspeak with words?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 첼로 경은 왜 언어로 말하지 않게 된 거야?

English (United States)(en-US): The human that created beauty with his cello?\nOh! So your last human was a musician!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 첼로로 아름다운 소리를 내던 인간?\n아! 첼로 경이 마지막으로 맡았던\n인간은 음악가였구나!

English (United States)(en-US): An undeniable prodigy?\nOh my......
But arrogant! So it’s true.\nGeniuses do look down on everyone else!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그런데 거만했다니! 모든 천재 인간들은\n콧대가 높단 말이 있더라니, 역시였어!

English (United States)(en-US): Oh, Sir Cello! The radio is blinking.
Dot’s human might be listening.\nShould I translate for you?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 뭉치의 인간도 듣고 있을지 몰라.\n내가 첼로 경의 말을 번역해 줄까?

English (United States)(en-US): Human, I was asking Sir Cello why\nhe no longer speaks in words.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 인간, 내가 첼로 경에게 왜 말을 하지\n않게 되었는지를 물어보고 있었어.

English (United States)(en-US): He’d like to share the story with you as\nwell! I’ll translate, you can count on me!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 너에게도 이야기를 공유하고\n싶대! 번역해 줄게. 나만 믿어!

English (United States)(en-US): One day, he hurt his hand\nreal bad from an accident.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그러던 어느 날, 첼로 경의 인간은\n사고로 손을 크게 다치고 말았어.

English (United States)(en-US): He got better but could\nnever play like he used to.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 저런.... 오랜 기간 끝에 회복했지만\n다치기 전 실력은 되찾을 수 없었대.

English (United States)(en-US): Everyone watching his\ndownfall sympathized,\nbut they laughed too.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 다른 이들은 그의 몰락을 지켜보며\n연민하기도, 유희처럼 즐기기도 했어.

English (United States)(en-US): Horrible melodies played in\nthe human’s nightmares.
Cello strings were the only source\nof comfort in a sea of cruel noises,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 날카로운 말들로 가득찬 세상\n속에서 그를 위로할 수 있던 소리는\n첼로 선율만이 유일했지만,

English (United States)(en-US): but the music he once loved\nwas now as stark as reality.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이젠 사랑하던 음악마저 그의\n현실만큼이나 지옥이 되어 버렸고

English (United States)(en-US): And in the end... the human\ngave up playing his life.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 끝끝내 인간은 자신의 삶을\n연주하기를 포기해 버렸대.

English (United States)(en-US): Sir Cello mourned, as he\nwas in love with his music.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 첼로 경은 그의 음악을\n사랑했던 만큼 깊게 슬퍼했어.

English (United States)(en-US): And while navigating\nthat grief he found music.
I shall play a tune vastly\nmore beautiful than\nwords alone, just for him.
Says Sir Cello.
Announcement. Everyone\ngather around in a circle.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 할 이야기가 있다 다들\n원을 이루게 모여 보도록.

English (United States)(en-US): Oooh, Edison’s got\nhot gossip! What’s up?
Went to clean the crater\nin the corner yesterday.
A dark place, left unkempt.
Witnessed something peeking\nout of the crater while preparing.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 도구를 준비 하던 중, 크레이터 안에서\n무언가 뻗어 나온 것을 목격.

English (United States)(en-US): A pale, thin hand\nresembling a branch.
Elongated fingers waved at\nme before disappearing.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 마디가 기이할 정도로 길게 뻗은 그 손이\n나에게 인사를 건네고는 사라졌어.

English (United States)(en-US): Scanned the crater immediately...\nfound nothing.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 직후에 크레이터 안을 확인해\n봤지만... 아무것도 없었음.

English (United States)(en-US): All that was left was\ndarkness like an abyss.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 남은 것은 심연과 같은 어둠 뿐.

English (United States)(en-US): Get outta here, Edison! Need\nnew glasses or something?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 하하! 에디슨. 잘못 본 거 아니냐?\n연구하느라 눈이 나빠졌나 본데!

English (United States)(en-US): Like that’s supposed\nto scare me. No way!
No, Sir Cello! My fire’s\nflickering cause it’s CHILLY.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아냐, 첼로 경! 내 불이\n흔들리는 건 추워서야. 크흠.

English (United States)(en-US): Are-are you playing creepy\nmusic on purpose? Stop it!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이, 일부러 무서운\n음악 연주하는 거지? 그만!

English (United States)(en-US): Hmm? I can’t find Edison.
Sir Cello, know where Edison is?
Stuck in the lab again. We haven’t\nseen hide or filament of her for days!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 또 틀어 박혀서 연구하고 있군. 며칠째\n필라멘트 코빼기도 안 보이잖아!

English (United States)(en-US): Wait, does that mean...
We don’t have to come\nto work every day?
You knew already? No way!
Then I’ll take a day off\nfrom cleaning too.
I’ll just go home and... well...
....Do what?
...You’re right. Life on the\nMoon with no work is boring.
I call it work, when actually it’s\njust a nice stroll with you guys.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 일이라고 부르지만, 사실은\n너희와의 산책과 다름 없으니까.

English (United States)(en-US): And I don’t have to think about\nsad things when I’m working.
....Ugh. Get those notes\nshaking, Sir Cello!
Today’s a day for cleaning\nthe small crater in the east.
Edison, Sir Cello. What are\nyou doing all the way here?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 에디슨, 첼로 경. \n내가 여기 있는 줄은 어떻게 알았어?

English (United States)(en-US): I thought you were\nstill cleaning?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아직 청소 덜 끝난 거 아니었어?

English (United States)(en-US): Your reflection in my eyes, Red.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내 눈동자에 비치는 네 모습을 봐, 레드.

English (United States)(en-US): Flickering. About\nto be snuffed out.
... Thinking of the human child?
Oh...! Didn’t mean to\nworry you. But you’re right.
When it’s silent like the\nuniverse has frozen over,\nI’m reminded of him.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 오늘같이 우주가 얼어붙은 듯\n고요한 날엔 그 애가 생각나서 말이야.

English (United States)(en-US): The boy that walked into the\nfreezing water willingly.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 시린 물 한가운데로 스스로\n걸어 들어간 그 애가.

English (United States)(en-US): Yeah. Time has passed but\nI haven’t forgotten a thing.
That deep deep loneliness I felt\nwhenever I peered into his day.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그 애의 하루를 들여다볼 때면\n느껴지던 깊고 깊은 외로움이.

English (United States)(en-US): If I could have been a\nmoment of warmth for him...
Would things be different?\nCould he have lived on?
These thoughts keep\nme up even now.
... You can always confide in us.
The same regrets apply to all of us.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그런 후회를 하는 건\n크레이터를 치우는 이 공장\n아래의 모두가 마찬가지니까.

English (United States)(en-US): (Rustling of wings from afar.)
(Squeaking of feelers.\nMoon moths or butterflies?)
(Rapid flapping of wings.)
Hmm. Is this on? (Zzzz-)
Do you copy, human? ... Seems\nto be malfunctioning. Oh well.
Will need to make adjustments\nafter observing the pattern\nin which it turns on and off.
In the meantime.
Here on the dark side, there’s not\nmuch to pique a human’s interest......
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이곳 달 뒤편에는 인간의\n흥미를 돋울 만큼\n흥미로운 이야기는 없다만.......

English (United States)(en-US): I suppose a story about\nhumans will suffice.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 역시, 인간에 대한 이야기를\n해 주는 편이 좋으려나.

English (United States)(en-US): I too observed a human\nduring my days as a worker.\nOne that studied the stars.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나도 직원 시절 관찰했던\n인간 하나가 있었다.

English (United States)(en-US): During a time when binoculars\nhad just been invented,\nthe human was a scholar of stars.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 망원경이 발명된 지 얼마\n지나지 않았던 시절,\n별을 탐구하던 인간이었지.

English (United States)(en-US): The human would gaze at the\nnight sky with her lover.
But her lover lost their\nlife in a sudden accident.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 하지만 그의 아름다운 애인은\n갑작스러운 사고로 생명을 잃었다.

English (United States)(en-US): ‘That star is where I’m\nheaded after I die’,\nwere their last words.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): ‘나중에 저 별에서 다시\n만나는 거야.’ 라는 말을 남기고.

English (United States)(en-US): The human was not aware\nof the name of the star.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 인간은 그들이 다시는\n만날 수 없다는 걸 알았다.

English (United States)(en-US): And so she threw herself into her work.\nEvery second of every hour\n... of every day.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그래서 인간은 연구에 더\n몰두했지. 매일, 매 시간, 매 초를.

English (United States)(en-US): Her obsession over\nreuniting with her lover\ngrew and grew. Until...
I calculated that I understood\nthe entirety of her loss.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나는 그의 상실을 온전히 이해하고\n있다고 판단했고,

English (United States)(en-US): And so I made mistakes.
Foolish mistakes, again\nand again, every night.
...... I can’t bring myself\nto tell you more.
But know this:
This transmitter was made so as not to\nrepeat the same mistake, human.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그 실수를 반복하지 않으려고\n개발한 것이다. 인간, 너와의 송신기를.

English (United States)(en-US): As the only method of overcoming\nignorance… is to converse.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 대화를 통한다면...\n무지는 언젠가 극복될 수 있으니까.

English (United States)(en-US): What if.
What if?
What if a human, albeit one with a\ntransparent soul and a pure heart,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 만약에, 아주 투명한 영혼과\n순수한 마음을 가진 어느 인간이

English (United States)(en-US): What if they become an astronaut and\nland on the dark side of the Moon?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 우주 비행사가 되어\n달의 뒤편에 착륙한다면 어떡하지?

English (United States)(en-US): What if they discover\nour beautiful factory,
And us, cleaning up filth?
Should we hide? Say hello?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 우리는 숨어야 하려나?\n아니면 인사를 건네야 할까?

English (United States)(en-US): Humans possess\na strong sense of curiosity.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 인간 또한 강한 탐구욕을 가진 종족.

English (United States)(en-US): Highly likely that they will\napproach and ask questions.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그는 분명 다가와 우리에게\n많은 질문을 쏟아 낼 것.

English (United States)(en-US): My flaming head will catch their\neye, right? I'm sure of it!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 불꽃 머리를 화려하게 뽐내고\n있으면 눈에 띄겠지? 분명해!

English (United States)(en-US): Maybe I’ll end up in the papers!\n‘Flameboy Warms Up Human’s Heart!’
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): NASA에 대서특필될 수도! 불꽃\n소년, 인간의 마음을 뜨겁게 데우다!

English (United States)(en-US): Rather, your presence will\nburn the human’s skin.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아니, 그 전에 인간의\n표피를 뜨겁게 데울 듯하다.

English (United States)(en-US): Human may acquire a burn. Their\nexteriors are far more fragile\nthan our understanding.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 인간이 화상 입을 수도.\n인간의 외피는 우리의 생각보다 연약함.

English (United States)(en-US): They cannot survive here\nwithout spacesuits.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그들은 우주복 없인\n이곳에서 살아남을 수 없음.

English (United States)(en-US): What if your flame were to burn\na hole through their spacesuit?
(Cue Beethoven’s Pathétique.\nA startling cacophony.)
Regardless, an emergency\nprotocol seems necessary.
Excuse me. I need time\nto come up with one.
It was a valid question, Red.
......That doesn’t make\nme feel any better!
Human. Humaaaan.
Couldn’t sleep, so I snuck\naround Edison to turn this on.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 오늘따라 잠이 오질 않아서\n에디슨 몰래 송신기를 켜 봤어.

English (United States)(en-US): Testing, one two three.\nCan ya hear me?
Hmm… I can’t stop thinking about\nthe last human I took care of.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 음... 마지막으로 꿈 제작을\n담당했던 아이가 자꾸 떠오르는 것 있지.

English (United States)(en-US): My last human.
You know, he really\nwas a sweet kid!
Always sharing his food with his friends,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 친구들에게 마지막 남은 반찬을\n항상 양보할 정도로 마음이 넓었고,

English (United States)(en-US): Always stooping down\nto say hi to a passing cat.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 지나가는 고양이와 인사하기 위해\n선뜻 주저앉아 손을 내밀\n정도로 경계가 보드라웠어.

English (United States)(en-US): But the world wasn’t sweet to him.
Is it always that way, or\nwas the kid just unlucky?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 원래 그렇게 이기적인 세상인 걸까,\n그 아이에게만 박했던 걸까?

English (United States)(en-US): ‘Cause he was weak? ‘Cause he was\n‘poorer’ than other humans?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 약해서? 인간 세계의 기준으로\n‘가난한 자’에 속해서?

English (United States)(en-US): ‘Cause he didn’t have\nadults to hide behind?
Don’t know. I bet it was a\nreally cowardly reason.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 모르겠어. 이해할 수 없는\n아주 비겁한 이유였다고 생각해.

English (United States)(en-US): The winter cold and the adults\naround him didn’t do jack for him.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그 아이를 에워싼 겨울도,\n주변의 어른들도. 결코 그에게\n온기를 되돌려주지 않았기에,

English (United States)(en-US): So I tried everything to make him\nwarm, but nothing reached him.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 난 모든 경우를 생각하며\n그를 데워 주려 했지만\n내 온기는 닿지 않았어.

English (United States)(en-US): Was I just not smart enough?
Or is the Moon too far from Earth?
......It’s all my fault.
So I… decided I’d burn even\nfiercer and hotter, just for him.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그래서 난... 그를 위해\n더욱 강렬하고 뜨거운\n불이 되기로 결심했어.

English (United States)(en-US): Who knows. Maybe that kid is wandering\nin space, far away from here.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 혹시 모르잖아.\n그 애가 지금 먼먼 우주를\n떠돌고 있을 수도 있는 거잖아.

English (United States)(en-US): And maybe one day\nwe’ll run into each other!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그렇게 우리가 언젠가\n만날 수도 있는 거잖아!

English (United States)(en-US): And then I can finally\nwarm the kid up.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그때, 그때 비로소 그\n아이를 데워 주면 되니까.

English (United States)(en-US): So you better root for me to\nkeep burning on! Can\nI count on you?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그러니 인간, 그때까지\n내가 타오르길 응원해\n줘야 해! 그럴 거지?

English (United States)(en-US): Do you remember?
When my shovel hit\nsomething in the ground.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 삽이 땅 속 무언가에\n부딪혔을 때 말야.

English (United States)(en-US): Yes. You had no idea\nwhat it was and summoned us.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 맞아, 네가 땅속 무언가의\n정체를 몰라 우리를 불렀잖아.

English (United States)(en-US): I studied, smelled, touched,\neven licked the resource.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 난 그 자원을 이리저리 보고,\n냄새를 맡고, 만져보고,\n또 핥아보기까지 했지.

English (United States)(en-US): And my senses confirmed\nwhat I already suspected.
That this new resource would\nbring about innovation on the\nMoon and the Factory!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이것은 달과 꿈 공장에 혁신을\n불러일으킬 신자원이라는 걸!

English (United States)(en-US): I left at once to retrieve my\nequipment from the laboratory
to begin experimenting on\nhow to convert it into fuel.
But I returned to discover\nthe resource missing.
I searched the Moon\nbut it hadn’t left a trace.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 달을 샅샅이 뒤져보았지만\n낌새도 없이 사라져 있었음.

English (United States)(en-US): My emotions had never\nbeen more intense.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그때만큼 내 감정이 요동쳤던\n때를 찾기는 쉽지 않아.

English (United States)(en-US): With that, I return to my lab.\nUntil the next time.
No, we made the right call\nby not telling her.
If Edison ever found out that\nher grand resource was just ice...
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그 대단한 신자원이 고작\n‘얼음’이었다는 걸\n알았다면 에디슨은...

English (United States)(en-US): We did too! You remember\nhow excited I was.
Edison may never get\nover it for the rest of time.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 에디슨은 그 실망과 충격을 영원히\n극복하지 못할 수도 있다고.

English (United States)(en-US): Hehe. True.
It was pretty funny watching Edison\nfreak out over the ice disappearing.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이미 녹아 없어진 얼음을 찾아\n헤매는 에디슨의 뒷모습도\n재미있었지!

English (United States)(en-US): Alright. I’ll lay off...
It’s days like these\nI miss being a worker.
I am in agreement.\nNo point in missing\nwhat cannot be retrieved.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 돌아갈 수도 없는 걸 그리워하면\n네 마음만 아픔. 일해라, 레드.

English (United States)(en-US): Still!
Still.
We weren’t outcasts,\nand we could send dear dreams\nto the humans dear to us.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그때는 우리가 사랑하는 인간들에게\n사랑스런 꿈을 보내 줄 수 있었어.

English (United States)(en-US): Nothing beat catching up on\nwhat they did each day\nbefore making dreams!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 꿈을 제조하기 전 그들의\n다채로운 하루를 재생해\n감상하던 업무는 매일의 낙이었지!

English (United States)(en-US): And those factory shucks\ndidn’t look down on us.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 재수없는 공장 놈들이 우리를\n무시하지도 않았고 말이야.

English (United States)(en-US): ...True.
It was a pleasure observing their\ntechnology develop so rapidly.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 경이로운 속도로 진화하던\n그들의 기술을 관찰하는\n것 역시 즐거웠다.

English (United States)(en-US): Pipe organs and semi-conductive\nchips, all incredibly intricate.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 파이프 오르간과 반도체 칩,\n놀라울 만큼 정교했음.

English (United States)(en-US): Beacons of intellect and will.\nI remember them clearly.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 지성과 집념의 집약체였지.\n아직도 기억 속에 생생하다.

English (United States)(en-US): Right, then we never would\nhave met, but don’t you still miss it?
But we already have met.
And I am fonder of you two\nthan you are aware of.
Now, back to cleaning.
Whoa. Whoa!
(Scuffling sounds)
Did I hear that right, Sir Cello?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 제대로 들은 것 맞지, 첼로 경?

English (United States)(en-US): eng
eng
eng
Hey, guess what?
Humans are really interested\nin this Moon of ours.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 인간들은 우리가 사는\n달에 참 관심이 많대!

English (United States)(en-US): The Greek myths said three\ngoddesses looked over the Moon.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그리스의 신화에서는\n달을 관장하는 세 명의\n여신들이 있다고 믿었대.

English (United States)(en-US): Artemis dealt with the cresent moon,\nSelene the full moon,\nand Hecate the waning moon.
WAY too cool and romantic.
Well, in Korea they believed\nrabbits lived on the moon.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그리고, 한국에서는 달에서\n토끼가 방아를 찧는다고 믿었대.

English (United States)(en-US): How’s that for\ncreative and adorable?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 지구에서 보이는 달의 앞면을\n보며 그런 상상을 한 거야!

English (United States)(en-US): True... science has made it\nrare for humans to believe in\nmyths or fairy tales.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그러게... 이젠 과학의 발전으로\n신화나 동화를 믿는 인간이\n흔치 않아졌어.

English (United States)(en-US): It’s kinda disappointing.\nNo, very disappointing.
I disagree.
Stories cast over facts are acceptable,
but their dedication to the truth,
is what I love to explore about humans.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 바로 내가 인간을 사랑하고\n궁금해하는 이유 중 하나다.

English (United States)(en-US): eng
eng
eng
Humans make\nirrational choices at times.
They speak with feti whose\nvocal chords are yet to operate.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 발화기관이 아직 작동하지 않는\n태아와 대화를 나누고,

English (United States)(en-US): And feel joy in the beauty\nof hopeless situations,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 가장 절망적인 상황에서도\n아름다움을 좇으며 기쁨을 느낀다.

English (United States)(en-US): despite not grasping\nthe full concept of beauty.
Irrationality. A puzzle\npiece that does not fit,
and certainly a human trait that makes\none want to contemplate.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 묘하게 앉아 바라보고\n싶은 인간의 그 기묘한 특성.

English (United States)(en-US): Yes, perhaps it is their irrational\nways that charmed me so.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그래, 어쩌면 그들이\n비합리적이기에 나를 그토록\n매료시킨 것일지도 모르지.

English (United States)(en-US): But are you aware, Sir Cello?
The fear that I may not understand\nthem fully paralyzes me at times.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 가끔은 그들을 온전히 이해할\n수 없을지도 모른다는\n공포에 마비된다.

English (United States)(en-US): Why… why they made\nsuch a choice back then.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 왜 그때... 그런 사고를 했으며\n그러한 선택을 했는지.

English (United States)(en-US): When all that is left is to ponder\nlike an echo with no reply,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 답 없는 메아리처럼 끊임없이\n짐작할 수밖에 없고, 당최\n이해도 납득도 되지 않을 때.

English (United States)(en-US): I freeze.
Is that truly what you think?\nThat we will never understand them?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 정말 그렇게 생각하나? 우리는 영원히\n그들을 이해할 수 없다고?

English (United States)(en-US): … Perhaps our world is far too simple.
…… If those are not\nof import, then what is?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): ...... 그런 게 중요하지 않다면\n대체 무엇이 중요한 거지?

English (United States)(en-US): True understanding occurs when one\nembraces without understanding?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 정말 이해하기 위해서는 이해하지\n못한 채로 받아들여야 한다고?

English (United States)(en-US): Embrace without understanding?
A sentence that contradicts itself.
Embrace the contradiction itself...
Boy. You really like embraces, huh.
(Sir Cello’s music. The rustling of\nmoon birds flocking together.)
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): (첼로 경이 연주를 시작한다.\n달의 새들이 모여드는 소리가 난다.)

English (United States)(en-US): (The dreamy harmony of bird chirps.)
See that space rock over there?
How long has it been drifting\nin this cold universe all alone?
Does it know how beautiful\nit is that all things must end?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 저 운석은 끝이 나는 것들의\n아름다움을 알고 있을까?

English (United States)(en-US): Up ‘til yesterday, I hoped my human kid\nwas floating through space like that.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 어제까진 나의 인간 아이도\n그렇게 우주를 떠돌고 있기를 바랐었어.

English (United States)(en-US): I thought maybe someday\nhe could wander right into me.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 오래 오래 떠돌다 보면 언젠가는\n만날 수 있을지 모르니까.

English (United States)(en-US): But...
I’m letting go now. Not\ngiving up. Just, facing facts.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이젠 놓을래. 포기하는 게 아니야.\n그냥, 인정하는 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): I’ve tried to be hopeful instead of\nsad, but this isn’t right for him.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 슬픔을 애써 희망으로 바꿔 왔지만,\n이건 그 애를 위하는 길이 아니었어.

English (United States)(en-US): Because.... because.
That split second of his life\nshined so bright.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그 애가 살아간 찰나의 시간이\n너무나도 눈부셨거든.

English (United States)(en-US): So much that its light\nreached me on the Moon.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그 반짝임은 달에 있는\n나에게까지 닿을 정도였어.

English (United States)(en-US): I want to protect\nhis special light. So I,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나는 그 애의 고유한 반짝임을\n지켜 주고 싶어. 그러니 나는.

English (United States)(en-US): I have to remember. How he\nbegan, and how he ended.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 기억해야만 해. 그 아이가 어떻게\n시작되었고, 어떻게 끝났는지.

English (United States)(en-US): His beautiful life that drew to\na close, a complete story.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 끝과 함께 하나의 이야기로\n완성되었던 아이의 아름다운 인생을.

English (United States)(en-US): So I’ll be letting go.
But there’ll always be\na lil’ pang in my heart,
and sometimes saltwater\nwill leak from my eyes.
But that’s okay. Right, Edison?
Were your head not made\nof flames, I would pat it.
I will settle for your shoulder instead.
I hated myself for not being\nable to be near you.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 다가갈 수 없고 곁에 있을 수 없는\n내 자신을 많이 원망했어.

English (United States)(en-US): But... if you’d known me.\nIf we’d been friends.
It occured to me that you\nmight not have wanted this,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 너는 내가 자책하는 걸 바라지\n않았을지도 모르겠다는 생각을,

English (United States)(en-US): me blaming myself.
You know,
You dreams turned darker, but I never\nimagined you were petering out.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 점점 어두워져가는 네 꿈을\n보면서도, 네가 꺼져 가고 있다는\n생각을 한 적은 한 번도 없었어.

English (United States)(en-US): You were as warm as\na strong flame to the very end.
Just the will, and the\ndogged instinct to live
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 살고 싶다는, 살아 있는 존재들의\n끈질긴 본능만으로는

English (United States)(en-US): and the dreams I sent\nfrom far far away
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 또 내가 아주 멀리서\n보내 주었던 꿈들만으로는

English (United States)(en-US): weren’t enough to stop\nthat warmth from petering out.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 네 온기가 끊어진 것을\n막을 수 없었던 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): Yes, I know now... that\nit wasn’t my fault.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그래, 나의 탓이 아니었다는\n걸... 이제는 알 것 같다.

English (United States)(en-US): It was hard to cope\nwith all the bad luck.
I used to wonder what you\nwould be like as an adult.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 사실 나는 어른이 된 너의\n모습을 궁금해하고는 했는데.

English (United States)(en-US): And I always will.
I don’t blame you.
But I resent that strength that\ncrushed you like it meant nothing
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 하지만 너무 약했던\n너를 아무렇지 않게 짓눌렀던\n그의 몹쓸 강함이 밉고

English (United States)(en-US): and the careless fence of a society\nmeant to keep you safe
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 너를 당연히 지켜 줘야 했던\n사회란 게 그토록 허술한\n울타리일 뿐이었다는 사실도 밉고

English (United States)(en-US): and that no one was there to hand you\na pair of mittens on that cold winter night.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 차디찬 겨울밤, 손난로\n하나 건네 주던 사람이\n하나 없었다는 것도 너무, 너무 미워.

English (United States)(en-US): Because I know that warmth would have\nbeen all it took for you to light up again.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 넌 그 조그만 온기로도 다시\n타오를 소년이었다는 걸 알아서.

English (United States)(en-US): Ohhhhhh. Oh.
Because... I wondered what\nyou would be like as an adult.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 왜냐하면... 난 진짜\n어른이 된 네 모습이

English (United States)(en-US): I really really did.
eng
eng
eng
Do you guys ever\nwanna go to Earth?
Earth? Now? Why think on it when\nwe have no means of going?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 갑자기? 지구? 갈 방법이\n없는데 그걸 왜 상상해야 하지?

English (United States)(en-US): Fine, whatever. It’s not like\nI was curious or anything!
… Earth is full of mysteries.
But the Moon offers resources\nof actual use for my research.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그러나 우주에서 나는 돌만큼이나\n내 연구에 실용적인 자원은 없다.

English (United States)(en-US): Though human scholars and\ntheir ideas do intrigue me.…
Sir Cello wants to learn\nthe melodies of Earth.
Like the gentle tunes of nature, blowing\nin the wind or pouring in the rain.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 특히 바람 소리나 빗소리처럼\n지구의 자연이 내는\n다정한 울림들이.

English (United States)(en-US): (The beating of moonfly wings rings\nfrom far away like clear bells.)
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): (달 나비의 맑은 종소리 같은\n날갯짓이 먼 발치에서 들린다.)

English (United States)(en-US): I concur. I too would miss the unique\nmelodies echoing on the Moon.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 동감함. 달에서만 특수히 공명하는\n선율들이 나 역시 그리워질 거다.

English (United States)(en-US): I’d give anything to go. But there\nare too many creatures on Earth.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나는 정말 가 보고 싶지만,\n지구에는 인간을 비롯한\n생물이 너무 많아.

English (United States)(en-US): Too, too…. TOO many!
My flames could hurt any one of them.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내 불길이 뜨거워 누군가 다칠지도 몰라.

English (United States)(en-US): The Moon, though cramped and barren,\nmight in fact be just wide enough for me.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 비좁지만, 척박해서 오히려\n널찍하게 느껴지는 달이\n나에겐 딱인걸.

English (United States)(en-US): Oh, and I can run anywhere\nand everywhere here.
I can ruuuuuuuuuuun…\n(Running footsteps grow quieter.)
Human! We’re here to...\nwell... say our goodbyes.
From what we've seen through\nDot’s eyes, you’ve been such\na beautiful and warm human.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 뭉치의 눈을 통해 틈틈이\n바라보았던 넌 정말 아름답고\n따스한 마음을 가진 인간이었어!

English (United States)(en-US): Yes, it was an honor to meet you.
We love you!\nEveryone loves you!
Sincerely and forever, from\nthe dark side of the Moon!
Sir Cello also says it was an honor. He says\nto tell many humans that we love them!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 첼로 경 역시 영광이었대.\n많은 인간에게 우리가\n그들을 사랑한다고 전해 달래!

English (United States)(en-US): Oh. The transmitter is about to break down.\nPerhaps it’s the outdated circuits.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이런. 구식 회로를 사용해서\n그런가. 고장 나기 직전.

English (United States)(en-US): No need for concern. Soon an updated\nversion will be released.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 걱정 마. 머지않아 달나라\n송신기 ver 2.를 출시할 것이다.

English (United States)(en-US): ‘Two-way communication’ is\non the horizon. Wait, human.
Then will this one... turn off soon?
Yes.
Human....... human..!\nI’m really gonna miss ya.
(Cello tuning noises sound\nlike the clearing of a throat.)
Nah! Let’s end things with a laugh!
So here’s a serenade\nfrom the three of us.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그러니 우리 셋이 함께 특별한\n이별 노래를 불러 줄게. 알았지?

English (United States)(en-US): Ahem! Listen up!\nYou might know this song.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 크흠, 크흠! 잘 들어야 해!\n인간에게도 익숙한 노래일 거야!

English (United States)(en-US): Sir Cello, cue music!
♫So long, farewell\nAuf Wiedersehen, goodbye♫
♫Goodbye, goodbye...... goodbye!♫
